<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 221, 432]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 805, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- Calculators must not be used in this paper.- You must show all necessary working clearly.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 587, 212, 601]]<|/det|>

INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 72, 567, 87]]<|/det|>
List of formulas 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 103, 787, 122]]<|/det|>
Equation of a circle with centre \((a, b)\) and radius \(r\). \((x - a)^2 + (y - b)^2 = r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 152, 674, 170]]<|/det|>
Curved surface area, \(A\), of cone of radius \(r\), sloping edge \(l\). \(A = \pi rl\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 200, 686, 218]]<|/det|>
Surface area, \(A\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(A = 4\pi r^2\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 245, 680, 273]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of pyramid or cone, base area \(A\), height \(h\). \(V = \frac{1}{3} Ah\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 293, 686, 320]]<|/det|>
Volume, \(V\), of sphere of radius \(r\). \(V = \frac{4}{3}\pi r^3\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 347, 656, 365]]<|/det|>
Quadratic equation For the equation \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\), 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 365, 555, 397]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 440, 225, 456]]<|/det|>
Binomial theorem 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 430, 904, 470]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^n = a^n + \binom{n}{1} a^{n-1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n-2}b^2 + \dots + \binom{n}{r} a^{n-r}b^r + \dots + b^n,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 477, 770, 515]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n-r)!r!}\) 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 546, 217, 562]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 545, 677, 585]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = a + (n-1)d \\ S_n = \frac{1}{2}n(a+l) = \frac{1}{2}n\{2a+(n-1)d\}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 622, 215, 638]]<|/det|>
Geometric series 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 620, 576, 700]]<|/det|>
\[u_n = ar^{n-1} \\ S_n = \frac{a(1-r^n)}{1-r} \quad (r \neq 1) \\ S_\infty = \frac{a}{1-r} \quad (|r| < 1)\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 733, 157, 749]]<|/det|>
Identities 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 730, 555, 780]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \sin^2 A + \cos^2 A &= 1 \\ \sec^2 A &= 1 + \tan^2 A \\ \cos e^2 A &= 1 + \cot^2 A \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 822, 241, 838]]<|/det|>
Formulas for \(\Delta ABC\) 

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[390, 816, 580, 893]]<|/det|>
\[\begin{align*} \frac{a}{\sin A} &= \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C} \\ a^2 &= b^2 + c^2 - 2bc \cos A \\ \Delta &= \frac{1}{2} ab \sin C \end{align*}\]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 0, 415, 72]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 73, 667, 89]]<|/det|>
Calculators must **not** be used in this paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[85, 105, 108, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 105, 136, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 105, 918, 137]]<|/det|>
On the axes, sketch the graphs of \(y=4|x-1|\) and \(y=|3x+2|\), stating the intercepts with the axes. [3]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 149, 845, 500]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[119, 519, 136, 535]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 519, 477, 535]]<|/det|>
Solve the inequality \(4|x-1| \leqslant |3x+2|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 519, 916, 535]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 72, 92, 84]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 90, 860, 315]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 334, 685, 366]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the curve \(y = a \cos bx + c\) for \(-180^{\circ} \leqslant x \leqslant 180^{\circ}\). It is given that \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 380, 346, 396]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a, b\) and \(c\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 537, 92, 549]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 537, 405, 565]]<|/det|>
The point \(A\) has coordinates \((-3, 6)\). The point \(B\) has coordinates \((7, -8)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 581, 737, 597]]<|/det|>
Given that the line \(A B\) is the diameter of a circle, find the equation of the circle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 581, 916, 597]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 811, 108]]<|/det|>
<pre>4 The polynomial p is given by \(\mathrm{p}(x)=a^{2} x^{3}+2 a x^{2}+a x+2\), where \(a\) is a positive integer. It is given that \(2 x+1\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 122, 136, 138]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 122, 311, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 122, 918, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 495, 136, 511]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 495, 327, 511]]<|/det|>
Hence factorise \(\mathrm{p}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 495, 918, 511]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 699, 136, 715]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 699, 664, 715]]<|/det|>
Hence show that the equation \(\mathrm{p}(x)=0\) has only one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 699, 918, 715]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 944, 315, 967]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 944, 545, 967]]<|/det|>
0606/12/F/M/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 78, 101, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 78, 136, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 78, 767, 96]]<|/det|>
Write \(2 x^{2}-2 x+3\) in the form \(a\left(x+b\right)^{2}+c\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are constants.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 78, 916, 94]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 266, 530, 282]]<|/det|>
<pre>It is given that \(\mathrm{f}(x)=2 x^{2}-2 x+3\), for \(x \leqslant p\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 298, 136, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 298, 636, 314]]<|/det|>
Write down the greatest value of \(p\) for which f has an inverse.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 298, 916, 314]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 422, 136, 438]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 422, 532, 438]]<|/det|>
Using this value of \(p\), write down the range of f.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 422, 916, 438]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 557, 136, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 557, 541, 573]]<|/det|>
Using this value of \(p\), find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 557, 916, 573]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 80, 520, 104]]<|/det|>
<pre>6 It is given that \(\tan \theta=\frac{\sqrt{5}}{5}\) and \(180^{\circ}<\theta<360^{\circ}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 115, 343, 131]]<|/det|>
<pre>(a) Find the value of \(\cos \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 115, 918, 131]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 302, 338, 318]]<|/det|>
<pre>(b) Find the value of \(\sin \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 302, 918, 318]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 456, 405, 472]]<|/det|>
<pre>(c) Find the value of \(\sec \theta+\cot \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[157, 479, 696, 508]]<|/det|>
Give your answer in the form \(\frac{a+b \sqrt{c}}{\sqrt{5}}\), where \(a, b\) and \(c\) are integers.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 484, 918, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[75, 80, 885, 430]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 435, 920, 469]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the curve \(y=\frac{5}{x+1}+2\) and part of the line \(y=2 x+1\) intersecting at the point \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 484, 360, 500]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label> Find the coordinates of \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 484, 916, 500]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 0, 460, 70]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 475, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label> Find the exact area of the shaded region.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 92, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 73, 485, 89]]<|/det|>
The first term of a geometric progression is 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 90, 574, 106]]<|/det|>
This geometric progression has a positive common ratio \(r\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 120, 530, 136]]<|/det|>
The first term of an arithmetic progression is also 10.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 137, 624, 153]]<|/det|>
This arithmetic progression has a negative common difference \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 167, 844, 199]]<|/det|>
The second term of the geometric progression is the same as the fourth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 200, 915, 216]]<|/det|>
The third term of the geometric progression is the same as the sixth term of the arithmetic progression.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 230, 136, 246]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 230, 364, 246]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(r\) and \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 230, 916, 246]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 727, 136, 743]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 727, 682, 743]]<|/det|>
Determine whether the geometric progression has a sum to infinity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 727, 916, 743]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[454, 945, 545, 956]]<|/det|>
0606/12/F/M/25

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 84, 104, 100]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 80, 466, 100]]<|/det|>
The point \(P\) lies on the curve \(y=\left(5 x+2\right)^{\frac{2}{3}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 101, 325, 117]]<|/det|>
The \(x\)-coordinate of \(P\) is 5.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 118, 693, 150]]<|/det|>
The normal to the curve at \(P\) intersects the line \(x+y=11\) at the point \(Q\). The point \(R\) is the reflection of \(Q\) in the tangent to the curve at \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[121, 163, 323, 179]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of \(R\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[940, 163, 966, 179]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 73, 453, 88]]<|/det|>
Continuation of working space for Question 10.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 80, 845, 315]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 334, 472, 450]]<|/det|>
In the diagram, \(\overrightarrow{O A}=\mathbf{a}\) and \(\overrightarrow{O B}=\mathbf{b}\). The point \(M\) is the midpoint of \(O B\). The point \(N\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{O N}=3 \overrightarrow{N A}\). The lines \(B N\) and \(A M\) intersect at the point \(X\). \(\overrightarrow{B X}=\lambda \overrightarrow{B N}\), where \(\lambda\) is a constant. \(\overrightarrow{M X}=\mu \overrightarrow{M A}\), where \(\mu\) is a constant.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 461, 175, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 460, 410, 477]]<|/det|>
Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[60, 0, 410, 72]]<|/det|>
 

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 80, 415, 96]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label> Find \(\overrightarrow{O X}\) in terms of \(\mathbf{a}, \mathbf{b}\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 80, 920, 96]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[120, 499, 136, 515]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 499, 422, 515]]<|/det|>
Hence find the values of \(\lambda\) and \(\mu\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 499, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[335, 917, 666, 933]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 75, 335, 91]]<|/det|>
<pre>12 It is given that \(y=x e^{3 x+2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 103, 227, 128]]<|/det|>
<pre>(a) Find \(\frac{\mathrm{d} y}{\mathrm{~d} x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[885, 106, 918, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 355, 350, 378]]<|/det|>
<pre>(b) Hence find \(\int x e^{3 x+2} \mathrm{~d} x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 918, 371]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]
